paragraphs.body: ${link_0} controlled the water inside seaweed to create a plant monster.
paragraphs.text: Huu controlled the water inside seaweed to create a plant monster.

paragraphs.body: Seaweed is a type of underwater ${link_0} found throughout the ${link_1}; the waters around the ${link_2}, ${link_3}, ${link_4}, ${link_5}, and the ${link_6} are all sources of the plant. In both the ${link_7} and Southern Water Tribes, seaweed is an important ${link_8}, but the tribespeople also use it in a variety of non-culinary ways.
paragraphs.text: Seaweed is a type of underwater algae found throughout the World of Avatar; the waters around the Fire Nation Capital, Republic City, Ba Sing Se, Jang Hui, and the Southern Water Tribe are all sources of the plant. In both the Northern and Southern Water Tribes, seaweed is an important food source, but the tribespeople also use it in a variety of non-culinary ways.

paragraphs.body: While ${link_0} was receiving a palm-reading from Aunt ${link_1}, ${link_2}'s famous fortuneteller, Wu made note of her unusually soft palms. Katara informed the fortuneteller that she used a special seaweed lotion that softened her skin, though it did not have the most pleasant of aromas.
paragraphs.text: While Katara was receiving a palm-reading from Aunt Wu, Makapu Village's famous fortuneteller, Wu made note of her unusually soft palms. Katara informed the fortuneteller that she used a special seaweed lotion that softened her skin, though it did not have the most pleasant of aromas.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0} explained to ${link_1} that seaweed was used in ${link_2} as a means of disabling ${link_3} ${link_4}.
paragraphs.text: Hakoda explained to Sokka that seaweed was used in tangle mines as a means of disabling Fire Nation warships.

paragraphs.body: Later on, ${link_0} ${link_1} taught his son, ${link_2}, how to make ${link_3}. He gathered seaweed from the ${link_4} near Ba Sing Se and used it to fill his mines, along with skunk fish. Intended to be used on ${link_5} ${link_6} trying to enter the ${link_7} capital, the seaweed in the mines would tangle the ships' propellers and render them dysfunctional, with the repulsive stench of the skunk fish forcing the ${link_8} to abandon their ships.
paragraphs.text: Later on, Chief Hakoda taught his son, Sokka, how to make tangle mines. He gathered seaweed from the Eastern Sea near Ba Sing Se and used it to fill his mines, along with skunk fish. Intended to be used on Fire Nation warships trying to enter the Earth Kingdom capital, the seaweed in the mines would tangle the ships' propellers and render them dysfunctional, with the repulsive stench of the skunk fish forcing the soldiers to abandon their ships.

paragraphs.body: During the ${link_0} on the ${link_1}, ${link_2} used ${link_3} to gather seaweed and create a giant monster. He controlled the behemoth from the inside with a technique known as plantbending, waterbending the liquid within the seaweed. The monster stayed close to the harbor and protected the invasion force's submarines from ${link_4}, as the submersibles were the invaders' only way out of the capital. The monster was eventually destroyed by a bomb dropped from a ${link_5}, leaving Huu unable to protect the submarines from harm and resulting in their subsequent destruction.
paragraphs.text: During the invasion of the Fire Nation on the Day of Black Sun, Huu used waterbending to gather seaweed and create a giant monster. He controlled the behemoth from the inside with a technique known as plantbending, waterbending the liquid within the seaweed. The monster stayed close to the harbor and protected the invasion force's submarines from tundra tanks, as the submersibles were the invaders' only way out of the capital. The monster was eventually destroyed by a bomb dropped from a Fire Nation airship, leaving Huu unable to protect the submarines from harm and resulting in their subsequent destruction.

paragraphs.body: Following the rescue of Hakoda from ${link_0}'s clutches, ${link_1} prepared a celebratory feast featuring foods from all four nations. Katara prepared seaweed stew, a Northern Water Tribe dish.
paragraphs.text: Following the rescue of Hakoda from Gilak's clutches, Team Avatar prepared a celebratory feast featuring foods from all four nations. Katara prepared seaweed stew, a Northern Water Tribe dish.

paragraphs.body: Aloe lotion infused with seaweed is a component of the "tea-leaf skin wrap", an elaborate spa treatment offered in Republic City. The treatment was a favorite of ${link_0}'s, and he recommended it to ${link_1}.
paragraphs.text: Aloe lotion infused with seaweed is a component of the "tea-leaf skin wrap", an elaborate spa treatment offered in Republic City. The treatment was a favorite of Prince Wu's, and he recommended it to Buttercup Raiko.

paragraphs.body: Seaweed is green in coloration and has a high water content. Both soft and smooth in texture, single strands of seaweed can be long, though they vary in size and thickness.
paragraphs.text: Seaweed is green in coloration and has a high water content. Both soft and smooth in texture, single strands of seaweed can be long, though they vary in size and thickness.

paragraphs.body: Huu's seaweed monster was gigantic in size and somewhat humanoid. It had a torso and two arms, but did not have legs or a head. Huu controlled the beast using waterbending from its core, which had a small wooden mask placed over it as a replacement for a head. The mask was triangular and had two carved-out, pointed eyes.
paragraphs.text: Huu's seaweed monster was gigantic in size and somewhat humanoid. It had a torso and two arms, but did not have legs or a head. Huu controlled the beast using waterbending from its core, which had a small wooden mask placed over it as a replacement for a head. The mask was triangular and had two carved-out, pointed eyes.

paragraphs.body: People in ${link_0} can enjoy a bowl of authentic ${link_1} seaweed noodles at ${link_2}.
paragraphs.text: People in Republic City can enjoy a bowl of authentic Southern Water Tribe seaweed noodles at Narook's Seaweed Noodlery.
